ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: D3.js, JavaScript, making pretty plots
I learned the basics of D3, which was useful. I also learned a lot of vocabulary about data visualizations that I do not think I will ever use again.
Lots of D3. Some visualization principles.
Javascript, css, html, d3
learned basics of data visualization in d3, a JavaScript library, learned about principles and design choices of data visualization
I learned how to think about and design the visualization of data.
How to make effective visualisations. D3
I learned about how to make good visualizations, how to use d3, and critique other visualizations.

I learned the best practices and techniques of visualizing data. A lot of the information is intuitive and just formalized through the textbook, but I saw that it really helped my visualization skills in this class and others.

I learned a ton about the different ways to communicate data to humans, both in terms of the theoretical (perceptual, information) underpinnings and overview of common ways to present data and their strengths and weaknesses. These skills will be quite valuable in the rest of my life as I consume and produce data visualizations.

Coding skills to achieve visualization.
Data and Information Visualization concepts, systems, idioms.
Paper reading skills.

The main knowledge areas that I gained from the course were an understanding of different types of data visualization techniques and how to choose the most appropriate one for a given dataset and purpose. In terms of skills, I developed a proficiency in using D3.js for creating data visualizations.
D3, JS, HTML, Data Vis fundamentals
D3 and HTML
Exploring datasets through visualization. Coding visualizations in Javascript using D3.
data visualization, especially interactions. Also som HCI perspectives.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strength - you learn how to use D3 javascript well
Weakness - the test are 50% of the grade and cover mainly useless information

Strengths: you learn javascript/d3
Weaknesses: lectures aren't recorded and not engaging, midterms are super obscure facts, only 2 office hours for psets

I think the content of lectures is not highly correlated with the assignments.
Also, I understand the policy that graduate students get more assignments and questions in exams. However, we do need more time for exam as we have more questions.

Strengths: Not too much workload, straight forward assignments
Weaknesses: Exams were mostly about memorizing small details, sometimes skills needed for assignments not taught in class and would have to be figured out by oneself
It's a very informative course that teaches good practical skills.

Strengths - the psets were really accessible and Sherry (the TA) was super helpful. All the assessments felt fair, and some of the readings were interesting.

Weaknesses - Lecture was not recorded so if you missed it, you completely missed the material.  D3 isn't really taught in class, and can be intimidating at first to figure out, but it's pretty accessible.

The course was really great. Consistent, predictable, fair workload that was rigorous but not overwhelming. The problemsets were enjoyable and interesting, and left enough room for visual design to be quite creatively fun.
I felt like the lectures werent really helpful since most things in the lecture was just a repetition of the readings, which covered everything quite comprehensively.
strength: The instructor communicated clearly and was easy to understand. She encouraged student participation in class.  Some guests are invited to hold lectures for us, from which I learned a lot.

Strengths
- Comprehensive coverage of different data visualization techniques and tools
- Clear and well-organized instructional material 

Weaknesses
- Heavy workload
Engaging and practical. Could have more code examples in class. The exams could be less about memorization and more understanding.

Strengths: Very comprehensive introduction to the field. The extra readings are interesting and complements the main book.

Weaknesses: The exam questions are sometimes too detailed. It can be quite difficult to prepare for the exam. Also for first exam I did not quite have time to finish all four coding questions.
The format of the exam is unnecessary. I think an open-notes version will be better, since there's too much materials and memorizing that much is impossible and unnecessary.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes if you meet the three criteria: 1) want a gut-ish CS elective, 2) want to work with data in the future, and 3) want to pick up JS. Otherwise, no. The problem sets are good practice but the textbook and lectures are too abstract. You get to see a lot of (usually) pretty plots and visualization beyond your typical bar chart and scatterplots. Though...  you can just google them too.
It would definitively have to be something they were interested in beforehand. The assignments are good, the tests are just so bad.
no. it's just so boring. take a different class.
Yes.
Yes it's a pretty decent elective. Bear in mind though that you have to do the readings

Possibly, if you're looking for a kind of lower workload/less intense CS elective and are interested in data vis. I did enjoy doing the psets after getting over the initial frustration of not knowing how to use D3. The exams were basically rote memorization from lecture slides and some parts of the readings, so when the midterms came up, you basically needed to memorize everything.
Yes - not necessarily for coding in d3, but for understanding the principles of visualization and have more intent behind what you're creating.

Yes, absolutely. It was a great class. The workload was not bad at all, and I got a huge amount out of it, far more than other CS classes with double or triple the workload. The assignments seemed carefully designed and the lectures were masterful, we had 9am lectures and even despite that it was the best and most rewarding class I took this semester (!).
No, the exams test your ability to recall random facts vS. Understand how to visualize data. That made studying for exams pretty difficult since any random fact could be tested
If the other one is willing to learn visualization skills, I would recommend it.
Yes. Data visualization is interesting and you can definitely learn a lot from Prof. Rushmeier.
Yes. Being able to build visualizations to explore data is a vital skill for CS students going into data science/big data engineer/etc.
yes, for student interested in this topic
